jnl96$uj07—12-12-96 09:48:18   JOURNAPGT            MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1996                       1
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  The Chief Justice said:
  “I have the honor to announce, on behalf of the Court, that the Octo-
ber 1995 Term of the Supreme Court of the United States is now closed
and that the October 1996 Term is now convened. Today’s orders of the
Court have been duly entered and certified and filed with the Clerk,
and they won’t be otherwise announced.”
                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 95–1708. Greater New Orleans Broadcasting Association, Inc.,
etc., et al., Petitioners v. United States, et al. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
for further consideration in light of 44 Liquormart, Inc. v. Rhode Is-
land, 517 U. S. ––– (1996).
   No. 95–1733. United States, Petitioner v. Terry J. Hatter, Jr., Judge,
United States District Court for the Central District of California, et
al. Because the Court lacks a quorum, 28 U. S. C. Section 1, and since
a majority of the qualified Justices are of the opinion that the case
cannot be heard and determined at the next Term of the Court, the
judgment of the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit
is affirmed under 28 U. S. C. Section 2109, which provides that under
these circumstances the Court shall enter its order affirming the judg-
ment of the court from which the case was brought for review with the
same effect as upon affirmance by an equally divided Court. Justice
Stevens, Justice O’Connor, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer took
no part in the consideration or decision of this petition.
   No. 95–2010. Edward B. Crouse, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit for further consideration in light of Koon v. United
States, 518 U. S. ––– (1996).
   No. 95–2090. Larry Fields, Director, Oklahoma Department of Cor-
rections, et al., Petitioners v. Bobby Battle, etc., and United States. On
jnl96$uj07—12-12-96 09:48:18   JOURNAPGT            MILES




2                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1996

petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Tenth Circuit for further consideration in light of the Prison Litiga-
tion Reform Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-134, 110 Stat. 1321.
  No. 95–8936. Loreta De-Ann Coffman, Petitioner v. United States.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Bailey v. United States, 516
U. S. ––– (1995).
   No. 95–9077. Noah Moore, Jr., Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Bailey v. United States, 516
U. S. ––– (1995).
   No. 96–112. Maryland, Petitioner v. Bruce Lamont Dennis. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Maryland. Motion
of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the Court of Appeals of Maryland for further consideration in light
of Whren v. United States, 517 U. S. ––– (1996).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for fees and expenses is granted, and
the River Master is awarded $4,752.67 for the period April 1–June 30,
1996, to be paid equally by the parties.
  No. 124, Original. Charles E. Collins, Plaintiff v. State of Alabama,
et al. Motion of plaintiff to expedite consideration of the motion for
leave to file a bill of complaint denied. Motion for leave to file a bill of
complaint denied.

4                         MONDAY, OCTOBER 7, 1996

  No. 94–820. Metropolitan Stevedore Company, Petitioner v. John
Rambo, et al. Motion of respondent Rambo for attorneys’ fees denied
without prejudice to refiling in the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit.
  No. 94–923. Ruth O. Shaw, et al., Appellants v. James B. Hunt, Jr.,
Governor of North Carolina, et al.; and
   No. 94–924. James Arthur Pope, et al., Appellants v. James B. Hunt,
Jr., Governor of North Carolina, et al. Motion of appellees to retax
costs denied.
  No. 95–1268. Maryland, Petitioner v. Jerry Lee Wilson. The motion
for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Byron L.
Warnken, Esquire, of Baltimore, Maryland, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.
   No. 95–1521. United States Department of State, Bureau of Con-
sular Affairs, et al., Petitioners v. Legal Assistance for Vietnamese
Asylum Seekers, Inc., et al. Motion of respondents to join additional
parties granted. Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Jus-
tice Ginsburg dissent. Motion of respondents for class certification
denied.
  No. 95–1605. United States, Petitioner v. Miguel Gonzales, Orlenis
Hernandez-Diaz, and Mario Perez. The motion for appointment of coun-
sel is granted, and it is ordered that Edward Bustamante, Esquire, of
Albuquerque, New Mexico, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent Miguel Gonzales in this case. The motion for appointment
of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Angela Arellanes, Esq., of
Albuquerque, New Mexico, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
respondent Orlenis Hernandez-Diaz in this case.
   No. 95–1682. Louisiana Legislative Black Caucus, et al., Appellants
v. Ray Hays, et al. Appellees are invited to file a response to the peti-
tion for rehearing within 30 days.
  No. 95–1694. Regents of the University of California, et al., Petition-
ers v. John Doe, etc. The motion for appointment of counsel is granted,
and it is ordered that Richard Gayer, Esquire, of San Francisco, Cali-
fornia, is appointed to serve as counsel for the respondent in this case.
   No. 95–1717. United States, Petitioner v. David W. Lanier. The mo-
tion for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Alfred
H. Knight, Esquire, of Nashville, Tennessee, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the respondent in this case.

                          Assignment Order

   An order of The Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice
White (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit during the period from November 18,
1996, through November 22, 1996, and for such time as may be required
to complete unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. § 294(a), is or-
dered entered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U. S. C.
§ 295.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice

   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                  Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–63. Vicki Hansberger, Dorothy Felton, and Teresa Proctor,
Appellants v. United States. Appeal from the United States District
Court for the Northern District of Georgia. Appeal dismissed as moot.

                Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 95–1826. D. L. Thomas, et ux., Petitioners v. American Home
Products, Inc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of
certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Banks v. ICI Americas, Inc., 266 Ga. 607, 469
S.E. 2d 171 (1996). Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting
opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice Breyer joins.
  No. 95–1830. James Gomez, Director, California Department of Cor-
rections, and Arthur Calderon, Warden, Petitioners v. David Fierro
and Alejandro Gilbert Ruiz. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of Pacific
Legal Foundation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
Motion of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further consideration in light of Cal. Penal Code Section 3604. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Breyer joins.
  No. 95–1956. Department of the Interior, et al., Petitioners v. South
Dakota, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit with instructions to vacate the
judgment of the United States District Court for the District of South
JNL96$1015—08-29-99 18:04:50       JOURNAPGT           MILES




168                       TUESDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1996

Dakota and remand the matter to the Secretary of the Interior for
reconsideration of his administrative decision. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Scalia, with whom Justice O’Connor and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 96–184. Life Insurance Company of Georgia, Petitioner v. Daisey
Johnson. On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of
Alabama. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the Supreme Court of Alabama for further con-
sideration in light of BMW of North America, Inc. v. Gore, 517 U. S.
––– (1996).

   No. D–1730. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arlen B. Mekler. Arlen
B. Mekler, of Wilmington, Delaware, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1731. In the Matter of Disbarment of Warren Ernest Brown.
Warren Ernest Brown, of Lafayette, Louisiana, is suspended from the

40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1732. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Silver. Jack Silver,
of Littleton, Colorado, is suspended from the practice of law in this

to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.

days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.

ald Lee Busby, of Temple, Texas, is suspended from the practice of law

of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the

                         Certiorari Granted

   No. 96–79. Sandra Jean Dale Boggs, Petitioner v. Thomas F. Boggs,
Harry M. Boggs and David B. Boggs. Petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. Brief
of petitioner is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, December 6, 1996. Brief of respond-
ents is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on
or before noon, Tuesday, December 31, 1996. A reply brief, if any, is to
be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Friday, January 10, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–270. Amchem Products, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. George
Windsor, et al. Motion of Chamber of Commerce of the United States
of America, et al. for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted.
Motion of National Association of Manufacturers for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted. Brief of petition-
ers is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on
or before 3 p.m., Monday, December 16, 1996. Briefs of respondents are
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Wednesday, January 15, 1997. A reply brief, if any, is to
be filed pursuant to Rule 25.3. Rule 29.2 does not apply. Justice O’Con-
nor took no part in the consideration or decision of these motions and
this petition and will take no part in the consideration or decision of
this case.
   No. 96–320. Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Michael Buckley. Motion of Association of American Railroads for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion of Consolidated
Rail Corporation for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
Motion of American Tort Reform Association for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Motion of Washington Legal Foundation for
leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion of Port Authority
of New York and New Jersey for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of Defense Research Institute for leave to file a brief
jnl96$1101—11-16-96 11:28:28   JOURNAPGT            MILES




228                      FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1996

as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit granted. Brief of peti-
tioner is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
on or before 3 p.m., Monday, December 16, 1996. Brief of respondent is
to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Wednesday, January 15, 1997. A reply brief, if any, is to

                      Order in Pending Cases
   No. A–310. Arkansas Term Limits, et al., Applicants v. Eugenia T.
Donovan, et al.; and
   No. A–320. Sharon Priest, Secretary of State of Arkansas, Applicant
v. Eugenia T. Donovan, et al. Applications for stay of the decision and
mandate of the Supreme Court of Arkansas, case No. 96–1120, decided
October 21, 1996, presented to Justice Thomas and by him referred to
the Court are granted pending the timely filing and disposition by this
Court of a petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition for a
writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically. In the
event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay shall
continue pending the issuance of the mandate of this Court. Justice
Stevens and Justice Ginsburg would deny the applications.
JNL96$1104—08-29-99 18:14:28      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1996                     231
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam

  No. 95–2025. California, et al., Petitioners v. Kenneth Duane Roy.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Judgment va-
cated and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
Opinion per curiam. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom
Justice Ginsburg joins.
                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. A–688 (O. T. 1995). Eugene Klecan, et al., Applicants v. New
Mexico Right to Choose, et al. Application for stay addressed to Justice
Scalia and referred to the Court denied.
   No. A–194. George C. Hook, Applicant v. Joe B. McDade, United
States District Judge for the Central District of Illinois. Application
for stay addressed to The Chief Justice and referred to the Court
denied.
   No. M–24. Credit Counseling Centers of America, Inc., Petitioner v.
Credit Counseling Centers. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition
for a writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–28. Carl K. Kramer, Petitioner v. City of Wichita, Kansas.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-
of-time denied.

   No. 96–262. Jon E. Edmond, Petitioner v. United States; Jake A.
Lazenby, Petitioner v. United States; Michael B. Leaver, Petitioner v.
United States; James A. Leonard, Petitioner v. United States; Robert
J. Nichols, Petitioner v. United States; and Donald H. Venable, Peti-
tioner v. United States. Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces granted. The brief of
petitioners is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing coun-
sel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, December 23, 1996. The brief of re-
spondent is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, January 22, 1997. A reply brief, if any,
is to be filed pursuant to Rule 25.3. Rule 29.2 does not apply.

(JOURNAL)              TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1996                  263
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                      Appeal—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–146. James R. King, Appellant v. Illinois Board of Elections,
et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Illinois. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United
States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois for further
consideration in light of Shaw v. Hunt, 517 U. S. ––– (1996) and Bush
v. Vera, 517 U. S. ––– (1996).

                     Orders in Pending Cases

  No. A–299. Federal Communications Commission and the United
States, Applicants v. Iowa Utilities Board, et al. Application to vacate
stay issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit addressed to Justice Ginsburg and referred to the Court denied.
  No. A–300. Association for Local Telecommunications Services,
et al., Applicants v. Iowa Utilities Board, et al. Application to vacate
stay issued by the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Cir-
cuit addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the Court denied.
  No. M–30. Kim D. Baker, Petitioner v. City of Phoenix. Motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
  No. 65, Original. State of Texas, Plaintiff v. State of New Mexico.
The motion of the River Master for award of compensation and fees is
granted, and the River Master is awarded a total of $1218.00 for the
period July 1-September 30, 1996, to be paid equally by the parties.
  No. 95–897. Francis Bernard Auer, et al., Petitioners v. David A.
Robbins, et al. Motion of League of California Cities, et al., for leave
to file a brief as amici curiae granted. Motion of the Acting Solicitor
General for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and
for divided argument granted.

the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1745. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth F. Crockett.
Kenneth F. Crockett, of Topeka, Kansas, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
                           Recess Order
  The Court will take a recess from Monday, November 18, 1996, until
Monday, December 2, 1996.

granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down of the judg-
ment of this Court.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 95–1948. United States, Petitioner v. Gloria Perez. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v. Ursery,
518 U. S. ––– (1996).
  No. 96–5337. Antonio Meza, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Koon v. United States,
518 U. S. ––– (1996).
  No. 96–5586. Alton Mills, Petitioner v. United States. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sev-
enth Circuit for further consideration in light of Ornelas v. United
States, 517 U. S. ––– (1996).

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

  No. 96–6724. Ronald Bernard Bennett, Petitioner v. Ronald J. Ange-
lone, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections. Application for
stay of execution of sentence of death presented to The Chief Justice
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit denied.
Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg would grant the application for
stay of execution.

(JOURNAL)              WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1996                 309
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 96–272. Metropolitan Stevedore Company, Petitioner v. John
Rambo, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Brief of petitioner to be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Monday, January 13, 1997. Briefs of respondents to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednes-
day, February 12, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday,
March 3, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–318. Daryll Richardson and John Walker, Petitioners v. Ron-
nie Lee McKnight. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit granted. Brief of petitioners to
be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Monday, January 13, 1997. Brief of respondent to be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Wednesday, February 12, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Mon-
day, March 3, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–491. Inter-Modal Rail Employees Association, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, et al. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit granted limited to Question 3 presented by the peti-
tion. Brief of petitioner to be filed with the Clerk and served upon
opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, January 13, 1997. Brief
of respondents to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, February 12, 1997. A reply
brief, if any, may be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, March 3, 1997. Rule 29.2 does
not apply.

(JOURNAL)               MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1996                     311
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”
                        Opinions Per Curiam
   No. 95–2082. United States, et al., Petitioners v. Laddie F. Jose,
Trustee of Jose Business Trust, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam.
   No. 96–5831. In Re Maria Luisa Costell Gaydos, Petitioner. On mo-
tion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner is allowed until
December 23, 1996, within which to pay the docketing fee required by
Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule 33.1 of
the Rules of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement by
Justice Stevens.
                   Appeal—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–471. Clarence E. Miller, et al., Appellants v. Ohio, et al. Ap-
peal from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Ohio. Judgment affirmed.
                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. A–1063. (O. T. 1995) Terrence Owens, Applicant v. United States.
Application for bail pending appeal addressed to Justice Souter and
referred to the Court denied.
   No. M–33. Charlie A. Marcus, Petitioner v. Jorge Carrasquillo and
City of Clearwater. Motion of petitioner to waive requirements of Rule
33.1 denied.
   No. M–34. Donald C. McMeans, Petitioner v. Hugh M. Leonard, et
al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari
out-of-time under Rule 14.5 denied.

312                     MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1996

   No. 105, Original. State of Kansas, Plaintiff v. State of Colorado.
Motion of Special Master for interim fees and expenses granted, and
the Special Master is awarded $107,199.16 for the period November 2,
1995, through October 18, 1996, to be paid equally by Kansas and
Colorado.
   No. 96–323. K. R., an Infant, by Her Parents and Next Friends, et
al., Petitioners v. Anderson Community School Corporation. The Solici-
tor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views
of the United States.
   No. 96–5658. Cary Michael Lambrix, Petitioner v. Harry K. Single-
tary, Jr., Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. The motion for
appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that Matthew C.
Lawry, Esquire, of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.
   No. 96–6240. Edward M. Lee, Petitioner v. The Fuji Bank, Ltd. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Peti-
tioner is allowed until December 23, 1996, within which to pay the
docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compli-
ance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 96–6244. Steven McKinney, Petitioner v. Washington. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Petitioner is
allowed until December 23, 1996, within which to pay the docketing fee
required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with
Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

al., Appellants v. American Civil Liberties Union, et al. On appeal from

nia. In this case probable jurisdiction is noted. Brief of appellants to be

p.m., Tuesday, January 21, 1997. Briefs of appellees are to be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Thurs-
day, February 20, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday,
March 7, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.

to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice of law
in this Court.
  No. D–1758. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael Xavier Morrell.
Michael Xavier Morrell, of Washington, D.C., is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                           Recess Order

  The Court will take a recess from Monday, December 16, 1996, until
Monday, January 6, 1997.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia,
Justice Kennedy, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 96–5369. Daniel Greene, Petitioner v. Georgia. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Georgia. Motion of petitioner
for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for a writ of certio-
rari to the Supreme Court of Georgia granted. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the Supreme Court of Georgia for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. M–1. Marion Lee Lawrence, Petitioner v. Secretary of the Treas-
ury. The motion for reconsideration of the order denying leave to file a
petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.

Inc. The motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certio-
rari out-of-time is denied.
   No. M–40. American Legion Post No. 3, Petitioner v. Separation of
Church and State Committee, et al. The motion to direct the Clerk to
file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time is denied.
   No. M–45. John J. Holtz, et al., Petitioners v. Jay Smith. The motion
to treat an untimely petition for a writ of certiorari as a conditional
cross-petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

Alaska. The motion of Alaska for additional time for oral argument is
granted, and thirty additional minutes are allotted for that purpose.
The motion of California for leave to participate in oral argument as
amicus curiae and for divided argument is denied.

et al. The motion of Special Master for compensation and reimburse-
ment of expenses is granted, and the Special Master is awarded a total
of $19,530.00 for the period June 1, 1996, through November 15, 1996,

practice of law in this Court.

days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.

   No. 96–6867. Joseph Roger O’Dell, III, Petitioner v. J. D. Nether-
land, Warden, et al. Application for stay of execution of sentence of
death presented to The Chief Justice and by him referred to the Court
granted pending the disposition by this Court of the petition for a writ
of certiorari. Should the petition for a writ of certiorari be denied, this
stay terminates automatically. In the event the petition for a writ of
certiorari is granted, this stay shall continue pending the sending down
of the judgment of this Court.

  No. 96–6867. Joseph Roger O’Dell, III, Petitioner v. J. D. Nether-
land, Warden, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis granted. Petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit granted limited to Questions
1 and 2 presented by the petition. Brief of petitioner to be filed with the
Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Thursday,
January 30, 1997. Brief of respondents to be filed with the Clerk and
served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Thursday, February
27, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Wednesday, March 12, 1997.
Rule 29.2 does not apply. Statement by Justice Scalia respecting the
grant of the petition for a writ of certiorari.

                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 96–651. James E. Gilbert, President, East Stroudsberg Univer-
sity, et al., Petitioners v. Richard Homar. Petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit granted.
The brief of petitioners is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon
opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, February 11, 1997. The
brief of respondent is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon oppos-
ing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 7, 1997. A reply brief, if
any, may be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on
or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, March 18, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–5955. Steiney Richards, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. Motion of
petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ
of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin granted. The brief of
petitioner is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing coun-
sel on or before 3 p.m., Tuesday, February 11, 1997. The brief of re-
spondent is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 7, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may
be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Tuesday, March 18, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
JNL96$0106—08-29-99 18:22:34     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                MONDAY, JANUARY 6, 1997                     401
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 95–1906. United States, Petitioner v. Vernon Watts; and United
States, Petitioner v. Cheryl Putra. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Motion
of respondent Cheryl Putra for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Motion of Morris L. Whitman for leave to file a brief as ami-
cus curiae granted. Judgments reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per cu-
riam. Concurring opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Jus-
tice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Kennedy.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–461. Sherryl S. Goffer, Petitioner v. Togo D. West, Jr., Secre-
tary of the Army. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit for
further consideration in light of the position asserted by the Acting
Solicitor General in his brief for the respondent filed November 25,
1996.
  No. 96–629. Arthur Calderon, Warden, Petitioner v. Steven H. Cas-
well. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Califor-
nia v. Roy, 519 U. S. ––– (1996).
JNL96$0106—08-29-99 18:22:34      JOURNAPGT          MILES

for the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of the position
asserted by the Acting Solicitor General in his brief for the United
States filed November 25, 1996.

                               Opinion
   No. 96–6556. Johnny Lynn Old Chief, Petitioner v. United States.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom The Chief Justice,
Justice Scalia, and Justice Thomas join.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 95–8736. Larry Osa Ogbomon, Petitioner v. United States. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Elev-
enth Circuit. Writ of certiorari dismissed as improvidently granted.

                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 96–663. Marvin Klehr, et ux., Petitioners v. A. O. Smith Corpora-
tion and A. O. Smith Harvestore Products, Inc. Petition for writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
granted. The brief of petitioners is to be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, February 21, 1997.
The brief of respondents is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon
opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March 21, 1997. A reply
brief, if any, may be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, April 7, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not
apply.
   No. 96–6133. William Bracy, Petitioner v. Richard B. Gramley, War-
den. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit granted limited to the following ques-
tion: “Whether a habeas petitioner who was convicted of a capital of-
fense and sentenced to death in a trial before a judge who admittedly
accepted bribes in other contemporaneous criminal cases is entitled to
discovery to support his claim that he was denied the right to a trial
before an impartial judge.” The brief of petitioner is to be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday,
February 21, 1997. The brief of respondent is to be filed with the Clerk
and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, March
21, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with the Clerk and served
upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m., Monday, April 7, 1997. Rule
29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–6298. Aaron Lindh, Petitioner v. James P. Murphy, Warden.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted.
JNL96$0110—01-29-97 19:21:14     JOURNAPGT          MILES

   No. 96–6225. Paul Silvers, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for

                        Attorney Discipline
   No. D–1743. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Walton Henderson,
Jr. Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1746. In the Matter of Disbarment of Michael J. Brady. Dis-
barment order entered.
   No. D–1747. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gregory J. Polischuk.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1748. In the Matter of Disbarment of Vincent T. D’Ambrosio.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1758. In the Matter of Michael Xavier Morrell. Michael Xa-
vier Morrell, of Washington, D. C., having requested to resign as a
member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on December 9, 1996, is
discharged.
   No. D–1763. In the Matter of Disbarment of David Dale Ellis. David
Dale Ellis, of Houston, Texas, is suspended from the practice of law in
this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
JNL96$0113—08-29-99 18:24:17     JOURNAPGT         MILES




                        MONDAY, JANUARY 13, 1997                  451
   No. D–1764. In the Matter of Disbarment of Floyd Mincey. Floyd
Mincey, of Dublin, Georgia, is suspended from the practice of law in
this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–1765. In the Matter of Disbarment of Andrew J. Fiore. An-
drew J. Fiore, of Pleasantville, New York, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1766. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Pitt. Howard
Pitt, of Greenwood Lake, New York, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

Tuesday, February 18, 1997.

(JOURNAL)               THURSDAY, JANUARY 16, 1997                  463
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                                 Order
   IT IS ORDERED that the revised Rules of this Court, today ap-
proved by the Court and lodged with the Clerk, shall be effective May
1, 1997, and be printed as an appendix to the United States Reports.
   IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that the Rules promulgated July 26,
1995, see 515 U.S. –––, shall be rescinded as of April 30, 1997, and that
the revised Rules shall govern all proceedings in cases commenced
after that date and, to the extent feasible and just, cases then pending.
JNL96$0117—01-29-97 19:23:05     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                FRIDAY, JANUARY 17, 1997                    465
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Granted
   No. 95–1918. Arkansas, Petitioner v. Farm Credit Services of Cen-
tral Arkansas, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit granted. In addition to the
questions presented by the petition, the parties are requested to brief
and argue the following question: “Should the case have been dismissed
by the district court for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, in light of
the Tax Injunction Act, 28 U. S. C. Section 1341?” The brief of peti-
tioner is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel
on or before 3 p.m., Friday, February 28, 1997. The brief of respondents
is to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Friday, March 28, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed
with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Wednesday, April 9, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–454. Associates Commercial Corporation, Petitioner v. Elray
Rash, et ux. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted. The brief of petitioner is to
be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before
3 p.m., Friday, February 28, 1997. The brief of respondents is to be
filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3
p.m., Friday, March 28, 1997. A reply brief, if any, may be filed with
the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or before 3 p.m.,
Wednesday, April 9, 1997. Rule 29.2 does not apply.
   No. 96–552. Rachel Agostini, et al., Petitioners v. Betty-Louise Fel-
ton, et al.; and
   No. 96–553. Chancellor, Board of Education of the City of New York,
et al., Petitioners v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al. Petitions for writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
granted. The cases are consolidated, and a total of one hour is allotted
for oral argument. In addition to the questions presented by these
petitions, the parties are requested to brief and argue the following
question: “Whether Rule 60(b) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
is a proper vehicle for obtaining the relief petitioner seeks.” The briefs

of petitioners are to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing
counsel on or before 3 p.m., Friday, February 28, 1997. The briefs of
respondents are to be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing

may be filed with the Clerk and served upon opposing counsel on or

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Scalia,

  The Court convened at 10:00 a.m. in the West Conference Room and
The Chief Justice said:
  “The Court will take a recess to attend the inauguration of the Presi-
dent of the United States.”
  The Court adjourned to the restored Supreme Court chamber at the
Capitol to robe. The oath of office was administered to Vice President
Gore by Justice Ginsburg. The oath of office was administered to Presi-
dent Clinton by The Chief Justice. The Marshal adjourned the Court
until Tuesday, January 21, 1997, at 10 o’clock.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–106. David S. Hess, et al., Petitioners v. Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for
further consideration in light of Atherton v. Federal Deposit Insurance
Corporation, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–548. United States, Petitioner v. Rochelle Ardall Crowder
and Horace Lee Davis. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Motion
of respondents for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co-
lumbia Circuit for further consideration in light of Old Chief v. United
States, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).

                        Attorney Discipline

  No. D–1730. In the Matter of Disbarment of Arlen B. Mekler. Dis-
barment order entered.
  No. D–1745. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth F. Crockett.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1761. In the Matter of Marcy Miller Hallock. Marcy Miller
Hallock, of Baltimore, Maryland, having requested to resign as a mem-
ber of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that her name be stricken
from the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this
Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on January 6, 1997, is
discharged.
  No. D–1767. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jerome J. Donnellon.
Jerome J. Donnellon, of Cincinnati, Ohio, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1997                    501
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 96–713. D. Dean Bibles, Director, Oregon Bureau of Land Man-
agement, Petitioner v. Oregon Natural Desert Association. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion per curiam.

                   Appeal—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–669. Johnny Dupree, et al., Appellants v. Mike Moore, Attor-
ney General of Mississippi, et al. Appeal from the United States Dis-
trict Court for the Southern District of Mississippi. Judgment affirmed.
Justice Stevens and Justice O’Connor would note probable jurisdiction.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

    No. 96–603. Catherine W. Griffin, Petitioner v. Medtronic, Incorpo-
rated. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Medtronic, Inc. v. Lohr, 518 U. S. ––– (1996).
   No. 96–964. American Life & Casualty Insurance Company, Peti-
tioner v. Anne C. Trostel, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further
consideration in light of the Economic Growth and Regulatory Paper-
work Reduction Act of 1996, P.L. No. 104-208, Sec. 2609.

                        Attorney Discipline
   No. D–1749. In the Matter of Disbarment of Ernest L. Keathley, Jr.
Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1768. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Scott Kaufman.
Robert Scott Kaufman, of Coral Gables, Florida, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1769. In the Matter of Disbarment of Burns H. Davison, II.
Burns H. Davison, II, of Des Moines, Iowa, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1770. In the Matter of Disbarment of James D. Henry, Jr.

practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

M. Lynn, of San Francisco, California, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

   No. 95–789. California Division of Labor Standards Enforcement, et

by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Thomas joins, concurring in part
and dissenting in part.

   No. 95–897. Francis Bernard Auer, Petitioner v. David A. Robbins,
et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia.
   No. 95–1694. Regents of the University of California, et al., Petition-
ers v. John Doe, etc. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Stevens.
   No. 95–7452. Kenneth Lynce, Petitioner v. Hamilton Mathis, Super-
intendent, Tomoka Correctional Institution, et al. On writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judg-
ment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Eleventh Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion by
Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins, concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment.
   No. 95–1065. Paul Schenck and Dwight Saunders, Petitioners v. Pro-
Choice Network of Western New York, et al. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment
affirmed in part and reversed in part, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for further proceedings
in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief
Justice. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Kennedy and
Justice Thomas join, concurring in part and dissenting in part. Opinion
by Justice Breyer concurring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 95–1268. Maryland, Petitioner v. Jerry Lee Wilson. On writ of
certiorari to the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland
for further proceedings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens,
with whom Justice Kennedy joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Kennedy.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 95–586. Wisconsin, et al. Petitioners v. Gerald R. Mueller, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Seventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of Semi-
nole Tribe of Florida v. Florida, 517 U. S. ––– (1996).
   No. 95–1415. Katherine Sabelko, et al., Petitioners v. City of Phoe-
nix, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of
Schenck v. Pro-Choice Network of Western New York, 519 U. S. –––
(1997).
   No. 95–1509. Douglas W. Luzik, et al., Petitioners v. Virginia, et al.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Virginia.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Supreme Court of Virginia for further consideration
in light of Auer v. Robbins, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Souter,

filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

     No. 95–1028. United States, Petitioner v. Robert S. Fadem and
Mary O. Fadem. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in
light of United States v. Brockamp, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).

   No. D–1752. In the Matter of Disbarment of Jack Wendell Frieze.

W. Maroney, of Portland, Oregon, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.

                         Assignment Order
  An order of The Chief Justice designating and assigning Justice
White (Retired) to perform judicial duties in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit during the period March 10 through
March 11, 1997, and for such time as may be required to complete
unfinished business, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 294(a), is ordered en-
tered on the minutes of this Court, pursuant to 28 U. S. C. Sec. 295.

                               Opinions
   No. 95–974. Arizonans for Official English and Robert D. Park, Peti-
tioners v. Arizona. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit with direc-
tions that the action be dismissed by the District Court. Opinion by
Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 95–728. Warner-Jenkinson Company, Inc., et al., Petitioners v.
Hilton Davis Chemical Co. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Cir-
cuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Gins-
burg, with whom Justice Kennedy joins.
   No. 95–1605. United States, Petitioner v. Miguel Gonzales, Orlenis
Hernandez-Diaz, and Mario Perez. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
JNL96$0303—08-29-99 18:32:10     JOURNAPGT        MILES




                         MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1997                    603
Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Ste-
vens, with whom Justice Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens joins.
   No. 95–1873. Guy E. Adams, et al., Petitioners v. Charlie Frank Rob-
ertson and Liberty National Life Insurance Company. On writ of cer-
tiorari to the Supreme Court of Alabama. Writ of certiorari dismissed
as improvidently granted. Opinion per curiam announced by The
Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1997                      609
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 95–1546. Shoketsu Kinzoku Kogyo Kabushiki Co., Ltd., aka
SMC Corporation, et al., Petitioners v. Festo Corporation. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Federal Circuit for further consideration in light of Warner-Jenkinson
Company, Inc. v. Hilton Davis Chemical Co., 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
  No. 96–874. Honeywell, Inc., Petitioner v. Litton Systems, Inc. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in light of Warner-
Jenkinson Company, Inc. v. Hilton Davis Chemical Co., 520 U. S.
––– (1997).
  No. 96–939. William A. Brandt, Jr., etc., et al., Petitioners v. Federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation, etc., et al. On petition for writ of certio-
rari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit for further consideration in light of Atherton v. Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).

   No. A–598. Geske & Sons, Inc., Applicant v. National Labor Rela-
tions Board. Application for stay addressed to Justice Thomas and re-
ferred to the Court denied.
   No. M–32. John Billy-Eko, Petitioner v. United States. Motion for
reconsideration of order denying motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.

States.

Technology Council. The Solicitor General is invited to file a brief in
this case expressing the views of the United States.

petitioner to expedite consideration of petition for writ of certiorari
denied.
   No. 96–6673. Steven L. and Christine L., Petitioners v. Board of
Education of Downers Grove Grade School District No. 58. Motion of
petitioners for leave to proceed in forma pauperis denied. Petitioners
allowed until April 7, 1997, within which to pay the docketing fee re-
quired by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance with Rule
33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
   No. 96–6867. Joseph Roger O’Dell, III, Petitioner v. J. D. Nether-
land, Warden, et al. Motion for appointment of counsel granted, and it
is ordered that Robert S. Smith, Esquire, of New York, New York, is
appointed to serve as counsel for the petitioner in this case.
   No. 96–7185. Garrit Bates, Petitioner v. United States. Motion for
appointment of counsel granted, and it is ordered that C. Richard Oren,

                          MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1997                     611
Esquire, of Rochester, Indiana, is appointed to serve as counsel for the
petitioner in this case.
  No. 96–7348. Carl S. Veale, et ux., Petitioners v. Citibank, F.S.B.

Petitioners allowed until April 7, 1997, within which to pay the docket-
ing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition in compliance
with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.
  No. 96–7397. Gennaro Guerriero, Petitioner v. Lufthansa German
Airlines, Inc. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied. Petitioner allowed until April 7, 1997, within which to
pay the docketing fee required by Rule 38(a) and to submit a petition
in compliance with Rule 33.1 of the Rules of this Court.

                         Attorney Discipline

 No. D–1764. In the Matter of Disbarment of Floyd Mincey. Disbar-
ment order entered.
  No. D–1765. In the Matter of Disbarment of Andrew J. Fiore. Dis-
barment order entered.
 No. D–1766. In the Matter of Disbarment of Howard Pitt. Disbar-
ment order entered.
  No. D–1778. In the Matter of Jeffrey D. Rudd. Jeffrey D. Rudd, of
Roanoke, Virginia, having requested to resign as a member of the Bar
of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the roll of
attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this Court. The Rule
to Show Cause, issued on February 18, 1997, is discharged.
   No. D–1787. In the Matter of Disbarment of Gerald Levy. Gerald
Levy, of Parsippany, New Jersey, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
  No. D–1788. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert C. Auriemma.
Robert C. Auriemma, of Towaco, New Jersey, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1789. In the Matter of Disbarment of Aaron David Denker.
Aaron David Denker, of Mt. Laurel, New Jersey, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                                Opinions

   No. 95–1598. Leroy L. Young, et al., Petitioners v. Ernest Eugene
Harper. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Tenth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Thomas.
   No. 95–1402. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Petitioner v. Es-
tate of Otis C. Hubert, Deceased, C & S Sovran Trust Company (Geor-
gia) N.A., Co-Executor. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Justice
Kennedy announced the judgment of the Court and delivered an opin-
ion in which The Chief Justice, Justice Stevens, and Justice Ginsburg
join. Opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom Justice Souter and Jus-
tice Thomas join, concurring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Breyer joins. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Breyer.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                   Appeals—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–1034. Playboy Entertainment Group, Inc., Appellant v.
United States, et al.; and
  No. 96–1108. Spice Entertainment Companies, Inc., Appellant v.
Janet Reno, Attorney General, et al. Appeals from the United States
District Court for the District of Delaware. Judgment affirmed.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–7621. Russell Calamia, Petitioner v. Harry K. Singletary, Jr.,
Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. On petition for writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Florida. Motion of petitioner for
leave to proceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the Supreme Court
of Florida for further consideration in light of Lynce v. Mathis, 519
U. S. ––– (1997).

                        Attorney Discipline
  No. D–1790. In the Matter of Disbarment of Bruce Michael Fried-
man. Bruce Michael Friedman, of Los Angeles, California, is suspended
from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

                               Recess Order
  The Court will take a recess from Monday, March 31, 1997, until
Monday, April 14, 1997.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1997                      663
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice O’Connor, Justice Kennedy,
Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam

   No. 96–858. Martin D. Lambert, Gallatin County Attorney, Peti-
tioner v. Susan Wicklund, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ
of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per cu-
riam. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg and
Justice Breyer join, concurring in the judgment.

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. M–67. Robert H. Williams, Petitioner v. Borg & Warner Automo-
tive Electronics and Mechanical Systems Corporation. Motion to direct
the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–68. John Babigian, Petitioner v. William H. Rehnquist, Chief
Justice of the United States, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a
petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–69. Kenneth Michael Rowls, Petitioner v. Marvin T. Runyon,
Postmaster General. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 95–1081. Ingalls Shipbuilding, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Director,
Office of Workers’ Compensation Programs, Department of Labor,
et al. Motion of respondent Maggie Yates for attorney’s fees and ex-
penses denied without prejudice to refiling in the United States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
   No. 95–1918. Arkansas, Petitioner v. Farm Credit Services of Cen-
tral Arkansas, et al. Motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave to
participate in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argu-
ment granted.

                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 96–957. Melvin Jefferson, Individually and as Administrator of
the Estate of Alberta K. Jefferson, Deceased, et al., Petitioners v. City
of Tarrant, Alabama. Petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme
Court of Alabama granted limited to the following question: “Whether,
when a decedent’s death is alleged to have resulted from a deprivation
of federal rights occurring in Alabama, the Alabama Wrongful Death
Act, Section 6-5-410 (Ala. 1975), governs the recovery by the repre-
sentative of the decedent’s estate under 42 U. S. C. Section 1983?”
  No. 96–6839. Hugo Roman Almendarez-Torres, Petitioner v. United
States. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit granted.

                          MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1997                   677
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 95–992. Turner Broadcasting System, Inc., et al., Appellants v.
Federal Communications Commission, et al. On appeal from the United
States District Court for the District of Columbia. Judgment affirmed.
Justice Kennedy delivered the opinion of the Court except as to a por-
tion of Part II–A–1. Concurring opinion by Justice Stevens. Opinion
by Justice Breyer concurring in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice
O’Connor, with whom Justice Scalia, Justice Thomas, and Justice Gins-
burg join.

of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Cir-
cuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Souter announced
by The Chief Justice.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 96–8400. Douglas McArthur Buchanan, Petitioner v. Ronald An-
gelone, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections, et al. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to The Chief Jus-
tice and by him referred to the Court granted pending the disposition
by this Court of the petition for a writ of certiorari. Should the petition
for a writ of certiorari be denied, this stay terminates automatically.
In the event the petition for a writ of certiorari is granted, this stay
shall continue pending the sending down of the judgment of this Court.

(JOURNAL)                  FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 1997                   687
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 96–454. Associates Commercial Corporation, Petitioner v. Elray
Rash, et ux. Motion of National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy
Attorneys, Inc., for leave to participate in oral argument as amicus
curiae and for divided argument denied.
                                Orders
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure be, and they
hereby are, amended by including therein amendments to Bankruptcy
Rules 1010, 1019, 2002, 2007.1, 3014, 3017, 3018, 3021, 8001, 8002, 9011,
and 9035, and new Rules 1020, 3017.1, 8020, and 9015.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Bank-
ruptcy Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1997, and shall gov-
ern all proceedings in bankruptcy cases thereafter commenced and,
insofar as just and practicable, all proceedings in bankruptcy cases
then pending.
  3. That THE CHIEF JUSTICE be, and hereby is, authorized to
transmit to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal
Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure in accordance with the provisions of
Section 2075 of Title 28, United States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure for the United States
District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including therein
amendments to Civil Rules 9 and 73, and abrogation of Rules 74, 75,
and 76, and amendments to Forms 33 and 34.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Civil Pro-
cedure shall take effect on December 1, 1997, and shall govern all pro-
ceedings in civil cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and
practicable, all proceedings in civil cases then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Civil Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of
Title 28, United States Code.
jnl96$0411—04-18-97 20:26:09    JOURNAPGT           MILES




688                        FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 1997

   Ordered:
   1. That the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure for the United
States District Courts be, and they hereby are, amended by including
therein amendments to Criminal Rules 16 and 58.
   2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Criminal
Procedure shall take effect on December 1, 1997, and shall govern all
proceedings in criminal cases thereafter commenced and, insofar as
just and practicable, all proceedings in criminal cases then pending.
   3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Criminal Procedure in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072
of Title 28, United States Code.
  Ordered:
  1. That the Federal Rules of Evidence be, and they hereby are,
amended by including therein amendments to Evidence Rules 407, 801,
803(24), 804(b)(5), and 806, and new Rules 804(b)(6) and 807.
  2. That the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of Evidence
shall take effect on December 1, 1997, and shall govern in all proceed-
ings thereafter commenced and, insofar as just and practicable, all pro-
ceedings then pending.
  3. That The Chief Justice be, and hereby is, authorized to transmit
to the Congress the foregoing amendments to the Federal Rules of
Evidence in accordance with the provisions of Section 2072 of Title 28,
United States Code.
JNL96$0414—08-29-99 18:36:19      JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1997                     689
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 96–8005. In Re Eileen Vey, Petitioner. On motion for leave to
proceed in forma pauperis. Motion for leave to proceed in forma pau-
peris denied. Petitioner is allowed until May 5, 1997, in which to pay
the docketing fees required by Rule 38, and to submit her petition in
compliance with Rule 33.1. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement
by Justice Stevens.

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. A–687. Simon Banks, Applicant v. Sean Randolph. Application
for stay addressed to Justice O’Connor and referred to the Court
denied.
   No. M–70. William R. Adams, et ux., Petitioners v. George W. Moore,
et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari
out-of-time denied.
   No. M–71. Johnnie L. Harrington, Petitioner v. Attorney General of
North Carolina. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–72. Marzug A. Al-Hakim, Petitioner v. Florida, et al. Motion
to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. M–73. Kenneth Bartlett, Petitioner v. United States. Motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. 95–1455. Janet Reno, Attorney General, Appellant v. Bossier
Parish School Board, et al.; and
   No. 95–1508. George Price, et al., Appellants v. Bossier Parish
School Board, et al. Motion of Harris County, Texas, et al. for leave to
file a brief as amici curiae denied.

                        Attorney Discipline

  No. D–1796. In the Matter of Jim D. Hamilton. Due to mistaken
identity, the order entered March 31, 1997, is vacated, and the Rule to
Show Cause is discharged.

                                 Order

   It is ordered that the call of the calendar, except for special assign-
ments, be suspended for the Term upon the conclusion of the cases
listed for hearing on Monday, April 21, 1997.

Justice Breyer would deny the application to stay.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
  No. 96–1297. United States, Petitioner v. Hughes Aircraft Company.
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Federal Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Federal Circuit for further consideration in light of
Warner-Jenkinson Company, Inc. v. Hilton Davis Chemical Co., 520
U. S. ––– (1997).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
   No. M–74. Stevie J. Stevenson-Bey, Petitioner v. Daniel E. Lungren,
Attorney General of California, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file
a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 96–1126. Iolab Corporation, Petitioner v. Ruth Hunter. The So-
licitor General is invited to file a brief in this case expressing the views
of the United States.

                         Certiorari Granted
  No. 96–1291. Dolores M. Oubre, Petitioner v. Entergy Operations,
Inc. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-

the petition.

   No. D–1759. In the Matter of Disbarment of Paul Neal Plust. Disbar-
