Disbarment order entered.
   No. D–1797. In the Matter of Disbarment of Norman Joseph Reed.
Norman Joseph Reed, of Las Vegas, Nevada, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1798. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph Dominic Sloboda.
Joseph Dominic Sloboda, of Miami Beach, Florida, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1799. In the Matter of Disbarment of Mark Bendet. Mark
Bendet, of Paterson, New Jersey, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–1800. In the Matter of Disbarment of John Rich Frye, Jr. John
Rich Frye, Jr., of Corpus Christi, Texas, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1801. In the Matter of Disbarment of Martin Louis Schwartz.
Martin Louis Schwartz, of Chicago, Illinois, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.

Charles W. Boyle, of Atlanta, Georgia, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, APRIL 23, 1997                    743
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                         Certiorari Denied
   No. 96–8624. John Ashley Brown, Jr., Petitioner v. Burl Cain, War-
den, et al. Application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court denied. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit denied.


                       Order in Pending Case
  No. 96–1683. In Re Arthur Calderon, Warden, Petitioner. Motion of
petitioner to expedite consideration of the petition for writ of manda-
mus denied.

                    Appeal—Jurisdiction Noted
   No. 96–1671. Franklin D. Raines, Director, Office of Management
and Budget, et al., Appellants v. Robert C. Byrd, et al. Appeal from
the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Motion
of the parties to expedite consideration of the appeal is granted. In this
case, probable jurisdiction is noted. The parties’ briefs are to be filed
with the Clerk of this Court and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Friday, May 9, 1997. Reply briefs, if any, may be filed
with the Clerk of this Court and served upon opposing counsel on or
before 3 p.m., Wednesday, May 21, 1997. Briefs may be submitted in
compliance with Rule 33.2 to be replaced as soon as possible with briefs
prepared under Rule 33.1. Rule 29.2 does not apply. Oral argument is
set for Tuesday, May 27, 1997, at 10 a.m.

                         Certiorari Denied
  No. 96–8028. Ernest Orville Baldree, Petitioner v. Gary L. Johnson,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit denied.

(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1997                    745
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and
Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 96–8081. Garry Thomas Allen, Petitioner v. Oklahoma. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Okla-
homa. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case
remanded to the Court of Criminal Appeals of Oklahoma for further
consideration in light of Cooper v. Oklahoma, 517 U. S. ——— (1996).

                        Certiorari Granted

   No. 96–1060. Lorelyn Penero Miller, Petitioner v. Madeleine K. Al-
bright, Secretary of State. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit granted.
   No. 96–8400. Douglas McArthur Buchanan, Jr., Petitioner v. Ronald
J. Angelone, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections, et al. Mo-
tion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis granted. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fourth Circuit granted limited to Question 1 presented by the petition.

certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 95–1100. Board of County Commissioners of Bryan County,
Oklahoma, Petitioner v. Jill Brown, et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment va-
cated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Jus-
tice Souter, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Breyer join. Dis-
senting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens and Jus-
tice Ginsburg join.
  No. 96–5955. Steiney Richards, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. On writ of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. Judgment affirmed.
Opinion by Justice Stevens.
  No. 95–1608. Michele L. Timmons, Acting Director, Ramsey County
Department of Property Records and Revenue, et al., Petitioners v.
Twin Cities Area New Party. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens,
with whom Justice Ginsburg joins, and with whom Justice Souter joins
as to Parts I and II. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 96–7167. Kenneth L. Larson, Petitioner v. Wisconsin. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District IV.
Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis and peti-
tion for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the Court of Appeals of Wisconsin, District IV, for further
consideration in light of Richards v. Wisconsin, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

   No. A–702. Lui Kin-Hong, Applicant v. United States. Application
for stay of mandate addressed to Justice Breyer and referred to the
Court denied. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice
Stevens joins.
   No. M–75. Kenneth Leon Milton, Petitioner v. World Savings and
Loan Association. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–76. Inge Maudal, Petitioner v. Texas Instruments Corpora-
tion, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. M–77. Lawrence Spears, Jr., Petitioner v. DSM Copolymer, In-
corporated. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of
certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 96–1060. Lorelyn Miller, Petitioner v. Madeleine K. Albright,
Secretary of State. The order granting the petition for a writ of certio-
rari is amended to read: The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted
limited to the following question: Is the distinction in 8 U. S. C. § 1409
between “illegitimate” children of U. S. citizen mothers and “illegiti-
mate” children of U. S. fathers a violation of the Fifth Amendment to
the United States Constitution?

792                        MONDAY, MAY 12, 1997

   No. D–1790. In the Matter of Bruce Michael Friedman. Bruce Mi-
chael Friedman, of Los Angeles, California, having requested to resign
as a member of the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be
stricken from the roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law be-
fore this Court. The Rule to Show Cause, issued on March 24, 1997,
is discharged.
   No. D–1803. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fred A. Schwartz. Fred
A. Schwartz, of Miami, Florida, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–1804. In the Matter of Disbarment of Donald R. Cooley. Don-
ald R. Cooley, of Springfield, Missouri, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1805. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brent Alan Schlottman.
Brent Alan Schlottman, of Chandler, Arizona, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

                               Recess Order
  The Court will take a recess from Monday, May 12, 1997, until Mon-
day, May 19, 1997.

                               Opinions

   No. 96–5658. Cary Michael Lambrix, Petitioner v. Harry K. Single-
tary, Jr., Secretary, Florida Department of Corrections. On writ of cer-
tiorari to United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join.
Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor.
   No. 96–491. Inter-Modal Rail Employees Association, et al., Peti-
tioners v. Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, et al. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Opinion by Justice O’Connor.
  No. 95–1455. Janet Reno, Attorney General, Appellant v. Bossier
Parish School Board, et al.; and
  No. 95–1508. George Price, et al., Appellants v. Bossier Parish
School Board, et al. On appeal from the United States District Court
for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case re-
manded to the United States District Court for the District of Colum-
bia Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of
this Court. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice
Thomas. Opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter joins,
dissenting in part and concurring in part.
   No. 95–1621. Harbor Tug and Barge Company, Petitioner v. John
Papai, et ux. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Kennedy, announced by The Chief Justice. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Ginsburg and Justice Breyer
join.
jnl96$ue12—06-05-97 17:10:52   JOURNAPGT          MILES




798                        MONDAY, MAY 12, 1997

  No. 96–203. Joyce Johnson, Petitioner v. United States. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Cir-
cuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice.

(JOURNAL)                  TUESDAY, MAY 13, 1997                    805
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                       Order in Pending Case
   No. 96–7151. Debra Faye Lewis, Petitioner v. United States. The
order granting the petition for a writ of certiorari is amended to read:
The motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is
granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is granted limited to the
following question: Whether petitioner was properly charged and con-
victed for the murder of her four-year-old stepdaughter under the As-
similative Crimes Statute, 18 U. S. C. § 13, and the Louisiana child mur-
der statute, La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 14:30(A)(5), and if not, whether the
sentence was proper?


                       Order in Pending Case
  No. A–807. Anthony Ray Westley, Applicant v. Texas. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court denied.
JNL96$0519—08-29-99 18:50:24     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, MAY 19, 1997                     807
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

   No. 96–538. Gary Frost and George Johnson, Petitioners v. United
States. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari
granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further consideration in
light of Johnson v. United States, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–1089. United States, Petitioner v. Michael Curtis Keys. On
petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judg-
ment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Johnson
v. United States, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–1323. City of Santa Ana, Petitioner v. Jess D. Hernandez, et
al.; and
   No. 96–1516. Jess D. Hernandez, et al., Petitioners v. City of Santa
Ana. On petitions for writs of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petitions for writs of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and cases remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Auer
v. Robbins, 519 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–6348. Allen McKinney, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Eighth Circuit for further consideration in light of Johnson v. United
States, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
JNL96$0519—08-29-99 18:50:24     JOURNAPGT          MILES




808                        MONDAY, MAY 19, 1997

                     Orders in Pending Cases

   No. A–416. Donald Wright, Applicant v. United States. Application
for bail addressed to The Chief Justice and referred to the Court
denied.
   No. M–79. Michelle Russell, Petitioner v. City of Bryan. Motion to
direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.
   No. 65, Original. Texas, Plaintiff v. New Mexico. The motion of the
River Master for fees and expenses granted, and the River Master is
awarded $2,758.00 for the period January 1 -March 31, 1997, to be paid
equally by the parties.
   No. 96–7171. Randy G. Spencer, Petitioner v. Mike Kemna, Superin-
tendent, Western Missouri Correctional Center. The motion for ap-
pointment of counsel is granted and it is ordered that John William
Simon, Esquire, of Jefferson City, Missouri, is appointed to serve as
counsel for the petitioner in this case.
   No. 96–8400. Douglas McArthur Buchanan, Jr., Petitioner v. Ronald
J. Angelone, Director, Virginia Department of Corrections, et al. The
motion for appointment of counsel is granted, and it is ordered that
Gerald T. Zerkin, Esquire, of Richmond, Virginia, is appointed to serve
as counsel for the petitioner in this case.

                        Certiorari Granted

   No. 96–1133. United States, Petitioner v. Edward G. Scheffer. Peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Armed Forces granted.
   No. 96–1462. Christopher H. Lunding, et ux., Petitioners v. New
York Tax Appeals Tribunal, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the
Court of Appeals of New York granted.
   No. 96–1482. Lexecon, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. Milberg Weiss Bers-
had Hynes & Lerach, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted limited to Ques-
tion 1 presented by the petition.

for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Fifth Circuit denied.

                               Opinions
   No. 95–1352. Gary Edwards and Tana Wood, Petitioners v. Jerry B.
Balisok. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further pro-
ceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Jus-
tice Scalia. Concurring opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
   No. 96–262. Jon E. Edmond, Petitioner v. United States; Jake A.
Lazenby, Petitioner v. United States; Michael B. Leaver, Petitioner v.
United States; James B. Leonard, Petitioner v. United States; Robert
J. Nichols, Petitioner v. United States; and Donald H. Venable, Peti-
tioner v. United States. On writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces. Judgments affirmed. Opinion
by Justice Scalia. Opinion by Justice Souter concurring in part and
concurring in the judgment.
   No. 94–1988. Camps Newfound/Owatonna, Inc., Petitioner v. Town
of Harrison, Maine, et al. On writ of certiorari to the Supreme Judicial
Court of Maine. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the Su-
preme Judicial Court of Maine for further proceedings not inconsistent
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom The Chief Justice, Justice
Thomas, and Justice Ginsburg join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins, and with whom The Chief
Justice joins as to Part I.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

(JOURNAL)                  TUESDAY, MAY 27, 1997                      835
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition

  No. 95–1385. Tana Wood, Superintendent, Walla Walla State Peni-
tentiary, et al., Petitioners v. Norman Gotcher, Jr. On petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir-
cuit. Motion of respondent for leave to proceed in forma pauperis
granted. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Edwards v. Balisok, 520
U. S. ––– (1997).

                      Orders in Pending Cases

  No. A–793. Gerald Einaugler, Applicant v. Supreme Court of New
York, et al. Application for stay of mandate addressed to Justice Souter
and referred to the Court denied.

to direct the Clerk to file a petition for a writ of certiorari out-of-time
denied.

Khan & Associates, Inc. Motion of Association of the Bar of the City
of New York for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Motion
of Business Roundtable for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae
granted. Motion of the Acting Solicitor General for leave to participate
in oral argument as amicus curiae and for divided argument granted.
   No. 96–1252. Professional Medical Insurance Company, et al., Peti-
tioners v. G. Thomas Murff. Motion of International Association of In-
surance Receivers for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted.
Motion of Transit Casualty Company for leave to file a brief as amicus
curiae granted.

                               Opinions

   No. 95–1726. United States, Petitioner v. George LaBonte, Alfred
Lawrence Hunnewell, and Stephen Dyer. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion
of this Court. Opinion by Justice Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 96–243. Bernadine Suitum, Petitioner v. Tahoe Regional Plan-
ning Agency. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Souter. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice O’Connor
and Justice Thomas join, concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment.
   No. 95–1853. William Jefferson Clinton, Petitioner v. Paula Corbin
Jones. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eighth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Stevens.
Opinion by Justice Breyer concurring in the judgment.
   No. 96–667. United States, Petitioner v. Robert E. Hyde. On writ of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by The Chief Justice.

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,

                         Opinion Per Curiam
  No. 96–1033. Lords Landing Village Condominium Council of Unit
Owners, Petitioner v. Continental Insurance Company. On petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice,
with whom Justice Breyer joins.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–540. United States, Petitioner v. Jerry Wayne Dunn. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment
vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of United States v.
LaBonte, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).

 No. 96–1640. Basic Energy Corporation, Petitioner v. Lawton
Chiles, Governor of Florida, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the

                                   Opinions
   No. 95–1764. Saratoga Fishing Company, Petitioner v. J. M. Mar-
tinac & Company and Marco Seattle, Inc. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Dissenting opinion by
Justice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Jus-
tice Thomas joins.
jnl96$uf02—06-13-97 17:06:01       JOURNAPGT          MILES




                               MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1997                  873
  No. 95–1918. Arkansas, Petitioner v. Farm Credit Services of Cen-
tral Arkansas, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case re-
manded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy.
  No. 96–79. Sandra Jean Dale Boggs, Petitioner v. Thomas F. Boggs,
Harry M. Boggs, and David B. Boggs. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment
reversed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals
for the Fifth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the
opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opin-
ion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice O’Connor joins, and with
whom The Chief Justice and Justice Ginsburg join, except as to Part
II–B–3.
  No. 95–1594. Barbara A. De Buono, New York Commissioner of
Health, et al., Petitioners v. NYSA–ILA Medical and Clinical Services
Fund, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom
Justice Thomas joins.
  No. 96–542. Walter McMillian, Petitioner v. Monroe County, Ala-
bama. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Eleventh Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by The Chief Justice.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens,
Justice Souter, and Justice Breyer join.

(JOURNAL)                  MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1997                      883
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                         Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 96–8796. Eileen Vey, Petitioner v. William J. Clinton, President
of the United States, et al. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in
forma pauperis denied. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting statement by
Justice Stevens. The Chief Justice took no part in the consideration or
decision of this motion.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–896. Jefferson County, Alabama, Petitioner v. William M.
Acker, Jr., and U. W. Clemon. On petition for writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit for further
consideration in light of Arkansas v. Farm Credit Services of Central
Arkansas, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–936. City of Anaheim, Petitioner v. California Credit Union
League. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further consideration in light of Ar-
kansas v. Farm Credit Services of Central Arkansas, 520 U. S. –––
(1997).

                      Orders in Pending Cases
  No. A–792. David Lee Smith, Applicant v. Colorado. Application for
stay addressed to Justice Stevens and referred to the Court denied.
  No. 96–1843. David Lee Smith, Petitioner v. United States Court of
Appeals for the Tenth Circuit et al. Application for stay addressed to
Justice Stevens and referred to the Court denied.

                        Certiorari Granted

ices, Incorporated, et al. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit granted.
   No. 96–1579. James Brogan, Petitioner v. United States. Petition for
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit granted.
   No. 96–1400. California and State Lands Commission, Petitioners v.
Deep Sea Research, Inc., et al. Motion of National Trust for Historic
Preservation, et al., for leave to file a brief as amici curiae granted.
Motion of Columbus-America Discovery Group for leave to file a brief
as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit granted.
   No. 96–1569. Daniel Bogan and Marilyn Roderick, Petitioners v.
Janet Scott-Harris. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted. In addition to the ques-
tions presented by the petition, the parties are directed to brief and
argue the following question: Are individual members of a local legisla-
tive body entitled to absolute immunity from liability under 42 U. S. C.
§ 1983 for actions taken in a legislative capacity?
   No. 96–1581. South Dakota, Petitioner v. Yankton Sioux Tribe, et al.
Motion of Montana Association of Counties for Reservation Counties
for leave to file a brief as amicus curiae granted. Petition for writ
of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit granted.

   No. D–1806. In the Matter of Disbarment of Thomas D. Morath.
Thomas D. Morath, of New York, New York, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.

vert. Stephen Bradford Calvert, of Stuart, Florida, is suspended from

within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.

(JOURNAL)               WEDNESDAY, JUNE 11, 1997                   903
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                      Habeas Corpus Denied
  No. 96–9321. In Re Earl Russell Behringer, Petitioner. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice Scalia
and by him referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas
corpus denied.
JNL96$0616—08-29-99 18:55:40     JOURNAPGT          MILES




(JOURNAL)                 MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1997                     905
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
   The Chief Justice said:
   “Today’s orders of the Court have been certified by The Chief Jus-
tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

                        Opinion Per Curiam
   No. 96–1104. Joseph P. Mazurek, Attorney General of Montana, Peti-
tioner v. James H. Armstrong, et al. On petition for writ of certiorari
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition
for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion per
curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Ginsburg and Justice Breyer join.

                 Certiorari—Summary Disposition
   No. 96–6114. Roger Collins, Petitioner v. George C. Welborn, War-
den. On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to pro-
ceed in forma pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted.
Judgment vacated, and case remanded to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further consideration in light of
Bracy v. Gramley, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).
   No. 96–8184. Willie Don Daniel, Petitioner v. United States. On peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Sixth Circuit. Motion of petitioner for leave to proceed in forma
pauperis and petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated,
and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth
Circuit for further consideration in light of Old Chief v. United States,
519 U. S. ––– (1997).

                     Orders in Pending Cases
  No. M–81. Gabor Kovacs, Petitioner v. Mental Health Services of
Orange County, Florida. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for
writ of certiorari out-of-time denied.

906                       MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1997

   No. M–82. Paul J. Grassia, Petitioner v. Fred A. Luongo, Sr., et al.

of-time denied.
   No. M–86. James Benjamin, Jr., et al., Petitioners v. Aroostock Medi-
cal Center, et al. Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ
of certiorari out-of-time denied.
   No. 120, Original. Original. State of New Jersey, Plaintiff v. State
of New York. The Report of the Special Master and the Supplement
are received and ordered filed. Exceptions to the Report may be filed
within 45 days. Replies, if any, may be filed within 30 days.

                        Certiorari Granted
   No. 96–827. Leonard Rollon Crawford-El, Petitioner v. Patricia Brit-

  No. D–1811. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brian R. Watkins. Brian
R. Watkins, of Lincoln, Nebraska, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

                           Recess Order
   The Court will take a recess from Monday, June 16, 1997, until
Thursday, June 19, 1997, and from Thursday, June 19, 1997, until Mon-
day, June 23, 1997.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

   No. 96–663. Marvin Klehr, et ux., Petitioners v. A. O. Smith Corpora-
tion and A. O. Smith Harvestore Products, Inc. On writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. Judgment
affirmed. Opinion by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with
whom Justice Thomas joins, concurring in part and concurring in the
judgment.
  No. 96–6867. Joseph Roger O’Dell, III, Petitioner v. J. D. Nether-
land, Warden, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice
Souter, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 96–272. Metropolitan Stevedore Company, Petitioner v. John
Rambo, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Ap-
peals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by
Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom Jus-
tice Scalia and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 95–1425. Lucious Abrams, Jr., G. L. Avery, William Gary Cham-
bers, Sr., and Karen Watson, Appellants v. Davida Johnson, et al.; and
   No. 95–1460. United States, Appellant v. Davida Johnson, et al. Ap-
peals from the United States District Court for the Southern District
of Georgia. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter,
and Justice Ginsburg join.
   No. 84, Original. United States of America, Plaintiff v. State of
Alaska. Exceptions of State of Alaska to the Report of the Special
Master overruled; Exception of the United States sustained; and the
recommendations of the Special Master are adopted to the extent con-
sistent with the opinion of this Court. The parties shall bear their own
costs. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Opinion by Justice Thomas, with

tice, filed with the Clerk, and will not be announced orally.”

   No. 96–1480. Louisiana, et al., Appellants v. United States. Appeal
from the United States District Court for the Western District of Loui-
siana. Judgment affirmed.

  No. 96–17. Northrop Grumman Corporation, Petitioner v. United
States, ex rel. Michael A. Hyatt. On petition for writ of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Petition for
writ of certiorari granted. Judgment vacated, and case remanded to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further
consideration in light of Hughes Aircraft Company v. United States ex
rel. Schumer, 520 U. S. ––– (1997).

                         Attorney Discipline

  No. D–1812. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert Steven Kaplan.
Robert Steven Kaplan, of Irvine, California, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
jnl96$uf23—07-22-97 16:37:51     JOURNAPGT          MILES




944                        MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1997

   No. D–1813. In the Matter of Disbarment of David S. Weisman.
David S. Weisman, of Los Angeles, California, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1814. In the Matter of Disbarment of Liang-Houh Shieh.
Liang-Houh Shieh, of Taipei, Taiwan, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1815. In the Matter of Disbarment of Brenda Powers Barnes.
Brenda Powers Barnes, of Santa Monica, California, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring her to show cause why she should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1816. In the Matter of Disbarment of Wayne N. Horne. Wayne
N. Horne, of Chicago, Illinois, is suspended from the practice of law in
this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.

                                Opinions
  No. 96–318. Daryll Richardson and John Walker, Petitioners v. Ron-
nie Lee McKnight. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
jnl96$uf23—07-22-97 16:37:51    JOURNAPGT           MILES




                           MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1997                       947
Breyer. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom The Chief
Justice, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 96–320. Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company, Petitioner
v. Michael Buckley. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded
to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit for fur-
ther proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion
by Justice Breyer. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg, with whom Justice
Stevens joins, concurring in part and dissenting in part.
   No. 95–1649. Kansas, Petitioner v. Leroy Hendricks; and
   No. 95–9075. Leroy Hendricks, Petitioner v. Kansas. On writs of
certiorari to the Supreme Court of Kansas. Judgment reversed, and
cases remanded to the Supreme Court of Kansas for further proceed-
ings not inconsistent with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Thomas. Concurring opinion by Justice Kennedy. Dissenting opinion
by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Souter join,
and with whom Justice Ginsburg joins as to Parts II and III.
   No. 96–6298. Aaron Lindh, Petitioner v. James P. Murphy, Warden.
On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Seventh Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit for further proceed-
ings in conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice
Souter. Dissenting opinion by The Chief Justice, with whom Justice
Scalia, Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 94–1474. Idaho, et al., Petitioners v. Coeur d’Alene Tribe of
Idaho, etc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment reversed in part, and case
remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit
for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this Court.
Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom
Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas join, concurring in part and concur-
ring in the judgment. Dissenting opinion by Justice Souter, with whom
Justice Stevens, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join.
   No. 96–552. Rachel Agostini, et al., Petitioners v. Betty-Louise Fel-
ton, et al.; and
   No. 96–553. Chancellor, Board of Education of the City of New York,
et al., Petitioners v. Betty-Louise Felton, et al. On writs of certiorari to
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judgment of
the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed,
and case remanded to the United States District Court for the Eastern
jnl96$uf23—07-22-97 16:37:51   JOURNAPGT           MILES




948                        MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1997

District of New York with instructions to vacate its September 26,
1985, order. Opinion by Justice O’Connor. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Souter, with whom Justice Stevens and Justice Ginsburg join, and with
whom Justice Breyer joins as to Part II. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Ginsburg, with whom Justice Stevens, Justice Souter, and Justice
Breyer join.


  Adjourned until Wednesday, June 25, 1997, at 10 o’clock.
jnl96$0625—07-21-97 19:11:04   JOURNAPGT            MILES




(JOURNAL)                WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1997                  949
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.


                          Certiorari Denied

  No. 96–9505. William Lyle Woratzeck, Petitioner v. Arizona Board
of Executive Clemency, et al. Application for stay of execution of sen-
tence of death presented to Justice O’Connor and by her referred to
the Court denied. Petition for writ of certiorari to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit denied.


                       Habeas Corpus Denied

  No. 96–9506. In Re William Lyle Woratzeck, Petitioner. Application
for stay of execution of sentence of death presented to Justice O’Connor
and by her referred to the Court denied. Petition for writ of habeas
corpus denied.


                               Opinions

  No. 96–270. Amchem Products, Inc., et al., Petitioners v. George
Windsor, et al. On writ of certiorari to the United States Court of
Appeals for the Third Circuit. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice
Ginsburg. Opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Stevens joins,
concurring in part and dissenting in part. Justice O’Connor took no
part in the consideration or decision of this case.
  No. 96–842. United States, Petitioner v. James Herman O’Hagan. On
writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth
Circuit. Judgment reversed, and case remanded to the United States
Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit for further proceedings in
conformity with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Ginsburg.
Opinion by Justice Scalia concurring in part and dissenting in part.
Opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom The Chief Justice joins, concur-
ring in the judgment in part and dissenting in part.
jnl96$0625—07-21-97 19:11:04   JOURNAPGT            MILES




950                      WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1997

   No. 95–2024. C. Martin Lawyer, III, Appellant v. Department of
Justice, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the
Middle District of Florida. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Sou-
ter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice O’Connor,
Justice Kennedy, and Justice Thomas join.
   No. 95–2074. City of Boerne, Petitioner v. P. F. Flores, Archbishop
of San Antonio, and United States. On writ of certiorari to the United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. Judgment reversed, and
case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth
Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opinion of this
Court. Opinion by Justice Kennedy. Concurring opinion by Justice Ste-
vens. Opinion by Justice Scalia, with whom Justice Stevens joins, con-
curring in part. Dissenting opinion by Justice O’Connor, with whom
Justice Breyer joins, except as to the first paragraph of Part I. Dissent-
ing opinion by Justice Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer.
   No. 95–1184. Dan Glickman, Secretary of Agriculture, Petitioner v.
Wileman Brothers & Elliott, Inc., et al. On writ of certiorari to the
United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Stevens. Dissenting opinion by
Justice Souter, with whom The Chief Justice and Justice Scalia join,
and with whom Justice Thomas joins except as to Part II. Dissenting
opinion by Justice Thomas, with whom Justice Scalia joins as to Part II.


  Adjourned until Thursday, June 26, 1997, at 10 o’clock.

(JOURNAL)                 FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1997                   953
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES


  Present: Justice Stevens, Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice
Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.
  Justice Stevens said:
  “The Chief Justice is attending a judicial conference in the Fourth
Circuit, so he will not be present today. Justice Scalia has an opinion
to announce in Printz v. United States and Mack v. United States.”

                               Opinion
   No. 95–1478. Jay Printz, Sheriff/Coroner, Ravalli County, Montana,
Petitioner v. United States; and
   No. 95–1503. Richard Mack, Petitioner v. United States. On writs of
certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
Judgments reversed, and cases remanded to the United States Court
of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity
with the opinion of this Court. Opinion by Justice Scalia. Concurring
opinion by Justice O’Connor. Concurring opinion by Justice Thomas.
Dissenting opinion by Justice Stevens, with whom Justice Souter, Jus-
tice Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer join. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Souter. Dissenting opinion by Justice Breyer, with whom Justice Ste-
vens joins.
   Justice Stevens said:
   “In the absence of The Chief Justice, I am now authorized to an-
nounce that the Court has acted upon all cases submitted to the Court
for decision. Disposition of items scheduled for conference will be re-
flected on an order list to be released later today. Accordingly, it is
ordered, that those cases remaining on the docket, but not ready for
consideration, are continued to the session of the Court beginning on
October 6, 1997.
   “The Court will be in recess from today, until the first Monday in
October 1997, at which time the October 1996 Term of the Court will
be adjourned, and the October 1997 Term of the Court will begin, as
provided by statute.
   “The members of the Court thank all of the Supreme Court staff for
their outstanding work, and their continued devotion to duty during
this Term.
   “The Court, the Bar and the public recognize the diligent work, com-
mitment, and professionalism of the Court staff. Such faithful service
JNL96$0627—08-29-99 18:58:18     JOURNAPGT          MILES




954                        FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1997

is exemplified by William Matthews, Supervisor of the Marshal’s Aides,
who is retiring after 40 years of service with the Court. Bill, would
you stand?
   “The fine work by the Court staff contributes significantly to the
accomplishment of the Court’s mission.”

                        Opinions Per Curiam
  No. 96–987. B. C. Foreman, et al., Appellants v. Dallas County,
Texas, et al.; and
  No. 96–1389. B. C. Foreman, et al., Appellants v. Dallas County,
Texas, et al. Appeals from the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Texas. Appeal in No. 96–987 dismissed, see Shaf-
fer v. Carter, 252 U. S. 37, 44 (1920). Judgment in 96–1389 vacated, and
case remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Texas for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion per curiam.
  No. 96–1383. William R. Pounders, Judge, Superior Court of Califor-
nia, Los Angeles County, Petitioner v. Penelope Watson. On petition
for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the
Ninth Circuit. Petition for writ of certiorari granted. Judgment re-
versed, and case remanded to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit for further proceedings in conformity with the opin-
ion of this Court. Opinion per curiam. Dissenting opinion by Justice
Stevens, with whom Justice Breyer joins.

                       Attorney Discipline

  No. D–1798. In the Matter of Disbarment of Joseph Dominic Sloboda.
Disbarment order entered.
  No. D–1817. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth Mack Williams.
Kenneth Mack Williams, of Glen Burnie, Maryland, is suspended from
the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable
within 40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be
disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
  No. D–1818. In the Matter of Disbarment of Robert S. Sosnay. Rob-
ert S. Sosnay, of Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, is suspended from the practice
of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.

                      Order in Pending Case

  No. 96–1578. Thomas R. Phillips, et al., Petitioners v Washington
Legal Foundation, et al. The order granting the petition for writ of
certiorari is amended as follows: The petition for writ of certiorari is
JNL96$0627—08-29-99 18:58:18    JOURNAPGT         MILES




976                       FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1997

granted limited to the following question: Is interest earned on client
trust funds held by lawyers in IOLTA accounts a property interest of
the client or lawyer, cognizable under the Fifth Amendment of the
United States Constitution, despite the fundamental precept of IOLTA
that such funds, absent the IOLTA program, could not earn interest
for the client or lawyer?

   No. D–1803. In the Matter of Disbarment of Fred A. Schwartz. Dis-
barment order entered.

of Los Angeles, California, having requested to resign as a member of
the Bar of this Court, it is ordered that his name be stricken from the
roll of attorneys admitted to the practice of law before this Court.
The Rule to Show Cause, issued on June 23, 1997, is discharged.

from the practice of law in this Court.

   No. 97–215. Arthur Calderon, Warden, Petitioner v. Thomas Thomp-
son. Order granting the petition for writ of certiorari amended to read
as follows: Motion of petitioner to proceed with 81/2 by 11 inch paper
granted. Motion of petitioner to expedite consideration granted. Peti-
tion for writ of mandamus denied. Treating papers submitted as a peti-
tion for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for
the Ninth Circuit, certiorari granted limited to Questions 1 and 2 pre-
sented by the petition. In addition, parties are directed to brief and
argue the following question: Did the Ninth Circuit, sitting en banc,
err in concluding that the three-judge panel “committed fundamental
errors of law that would result in manifest injustice” sufficient to jus-
tify recalling the mandate?

disbarred from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1849. In the Matter of Disbarment of Neal Yarborough Pick-
ett. Neal Yarborough Pickett, of Houston, Texas, is suspended from the
practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within
40 days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred
from the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1850. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lyn H. Marcus. Lyn H.
Marcus, of Los Angeles, California, is suspended from the practice of
law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days,
requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the
practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1851. In the Matter of Disbarment of Nicholas Smith. Nicho-
las Smith, of Plymouth, Michigan, is suspended from the practice of law
in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40 days, requiring
him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from the practice
of law in this Court.
   No. D–1852. In the Matter of Disbarment of Lawrence R. Greene.
Lawrence R. Greene, of Detroit, Michigan, is suspended from the prac-
tice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue, returnable within 40
days, requiring him to show cause why he should not be disbarred from
the practice of law in this Court.
   No. D–1853. In the Matter of Disbarment of Kenneth W. Thornton,
Jr. Kenneth W. Thornton, Jr., of Georgetown, South Carolina, is sus-
pended from the practice of law in this Court, and a rule will issue,

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES

  Present: Chief Justice Rehnquist, Justice Stevens, Justice O’Connor,
Justice Scalia, Justice Kennedy, Justice Souter, Justice Thomas, Justice
Ginsburg, and Justice Breyer.

                       Order in Pending Case
  No. M–9. Dwight Dwayne Adanandus, Petitioner v. Gary L. Johnson,
Director, Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Institutional Division.
Motion to direct the Clerk to file a petition for writ of certiorari out-of-
time denied. Application for stay of execution of sentence of death pre-
sented to Justice Scalia and by him referred to the Court denied.
